entry.et: Middle English, against, from, with, from Old English; akin to Old English wither against, Old High German widar against, back, Sanskrit vi apart

def.dt: :in opposition to :against had a fight with his brother
:so as to be separated or detached from broke with her family

dt.un: used as a function word to indicate a participant in an action, transaction, or arrangement works with his father a talk with a friend got into an accident with the car
used as a function word to indicate the object of attention, behavior, or feeling get tough with him angry with her

def.dt: :in respect to :so far as concerns on friendly terms with all nations

dt.un: used to indicate the object of an adverbial expression of imperative force off with his head

def.dt: :over on no longer has any influence with them
:in the performance, operation, or use of the trouble with this machine

dt.un: used as a function word to indicate the object of a statement of comparison or equality a dress identical with her hostess's
used as a function word to express agreement or sympathy must conclude, with you, that the painting is a forgery

def.dt: :on the side of :for if he's for lower taxes, I'm with him
:as well as can pitch with the best of them

dt.un: used as a function word to indicate combination, accompaniment, presence, or addition heat milk with honey went there with her his money, with his wife's, comes to a million

def.dt: :inclusive of costs $5 with the tax
:in the judgment or estimation of stood well with her classmates
:in or according to the experience or practice of with many of us, our ideas seem to fall by the wayside W. J. Reilly

dt.un: used as a function word to indicate the means, cause, agent, or instrumentality hit him with a rock pale with anger threatened with tuberculosis he amused the crowd with his antics

def.dt: :by the direct act of

dt.un: used as a function word to indicate manner of action ran with effort acknowledge your contribution with thanks
used as a function word to indicate an attendant fact or circumstance stood there with his hat on
used as a function word to indicate a result attendant on a specified action got off with a light sentence

def.dt: :in possession of :having came with good news
:in the possession or care of left the money with her mother
:characterized or distinguished by a person with a sharp nose

dt.un: used as a function word to indicate a close association in time with the outbreak of war they went home mellows with time

def.dt: :in proportion to the pressure varies with the depth
:in spite of :notwithstanding a really tip-top man, with all his wrongheadedness H. J. Laski
:except for finds that, with one group of omissions and one important addition, they reflect that curriculum Gilbert Highet
:in the direction of with the wind with the grain

entry.et: Middle English, from Old English withthe; akin to Old English wīthig withy

def.dt: :a slender flexible branch or twig
:one used as a band or line

entry.et: Middle English, from Latin capitalis, from capit-, caput (see capital)

def.dt: :of or conforming to the series A, B, C, etc. rather than a, b, c, etc.
:punishable by death a capital crime
:involving execution capital punishment
:most serious a capital error
:chief in importance or influence capital ships the capital importance of criticism in the work of creation itself T. S. Eliot
:being the seat of government
:of or relating to capital (see capital)
:relating to or being assets that add to the long-term net worth of a corporation capital improvements
:excellent a capital book

dt.un: used with a following capital letter to emphasize or qualify a preceding word not an accident but murder with a capital M desired romance with a capital R

entry.et: Middle English, from Old English cild; akin to Gothic kilthei womb, and perhaps to Sanskrit jaṭhara belly

def.dt: :an unborn or recently born person
:a female infant
:a young person especially between infancy and youth
:a childlike or childish person
:a person not yet of age
:a youth of noble birth
:a son or daughter of human parents
:descendant
:one strongly influenced by another or by a place or state of affairs
:product result barbed wire … is truly a child of the plains W. P. Webb
:pregnant

art.capt: eye 1a: 1 optic nerve, 2 blind spot, 3 fovea, 4 sclera, 5 choroid, 6 retina, 7 ciliary body, 8 posterior chamber, 9 anterior chamber, 10 cornea, 11 lens, 12 iris, 13 suspensory ligament, 14 conjunctiva, 15 vitreous humor

entry.et: Middle English, from Old English ēage; akin to Old High German ouga eye, Latin oculus, Greek ōps eye, face, Sanskrit akṣi eye

def.dt: :a specialized light-sensitive sensory structure of animals that in nearly all vertebrates, most arthropods, and some mollusks is the image-forming organ of sight
:the nearly spherical usually paired hollow organ of sight in vertebrates that is filled with a jellylike material, is lined with a photosensitive retina, and is lodged in a bony orbit in the skull
:all the visible structures within and surrounding the orbit and including eyelids, eyelashes, and eyebrows
:the faculty of seeing with eyes
:the faculty of intellectual or aesthetic perception or appreciation an eye for beauty
:skill or ability dependent upon eyesight a batter with a good eye
:look glance cast an eager eye
:an attentive look kept an eye on his valuables
:attention notice caught his eye
:close observation :scrutiny works under the eye of her boss in the public eye
:point of view judgment beauty is in the eye of the beholder often used in plural an offender in the eyes of the law
:something having an appearance suggestive of an eye: as
:the hole through the head of a needle
:a usually circular marking (as on a peacock's tail)
:loop
:a loop or catch to receive a hook
:an undeveloped bud (as on a potato)
:an area like a hole in the center of a tropical cyclone marked by only light winds or complete calm with no precipitation
:the center of a flower especially when differently colored or marked
:the disk of a composite
:a triangular piece of beef cut from between the top and bottom of a round
:the chief muscle of a chop
:a compact mass of muscular tissue usually embedded in fat in a rib or loin cut of meat
:a device (as a photoelectric cell) that functions in a manner analogous to human vision
:something central :center the eye of the problem Norman Mailer
:the direction from which the wind is blowing
:retribution in kind

dt.un: used to express mild disagreement or sometimes surprise a diamond, my eye! That's glass

def.dt: :with awareness or contemplation of with an eye to the future
:with the object of built the house with an eye to adding on later

art.cap: eye 1a: 1 optic nerve, 2 blind spot, 3 fovea, 4 sclera, 5 choroid, 6 retina, 7 ciliary body, 8 posterior chamber, 9 anterior chamber, 10 cornea, 11 lens, 12 iris, 13 suspensory ligament, 14 conjunctiva, 15 vitreous humor

def.dt: :moving or capable of moving in the air
:moving or made by moving rapidly flying feet a flying leap
:very brief
:intended for ready movement or action a flying squad car
:having stylized wings used especially of livestock brand marks
:of or relating to the operation of aircraft a flying club
:traversed or to be traversed (as in speed-record trials) after a running start a flying kilometer
:with complete or eminent success
:a dress glove made of kid leather
:with special consideration
:a panting breath
:the visible movement of the chest accompanying such a breath
:a throbbing or puffing sound
:an outer garment covering each leg separately and usually extending from the waist to the ankle usually used in plural
:men's underpants
:pantie
:in an embarrassing position (as of being unprepared to act)

entry.et: Middle English resoun, from Anglo-French raisun, from Latin ration-, ratio reason, computation, from reri to calculate, think; probably akin to Gothic rathjo account, explanation

def.dt: :a statement offered in explanation or justification gave reasons that were quite satisfactory
:a rational ground or motive a good reason to act soon
:a sufficient ground of explanation or of logical defense
:something (as a principle or law) that supports a conclusion or explains a fact the reasons behind her client's action
:the thing that makes some fact intelligible :cause the reason for earthquakes the real reason why he wanted me to stay Graham Greene
:the power of comprehending, inferring, or thinking especially in orderly rational ways :intelligence
:proper exercise of the mind
:sanity
:the sum of the intellectual powers
:treatment that affords satisfaction
:rightly justifiably
:within reasonable limits
:with good cause
